p:
While persistent organic pollutants (POPs) and mercury contamination of the marine environment have long been recognized as global problems
1– 3 , the effects of climate change in exacerbating pollutant toxicity and bioaccumulation have recently drawn attention from eco-toxicological research arenas
4– 11 . MeHg and PCBs are amongst the most prevalent chemicals in marine food webs, affecting the health of marine organisms
12, 13 . Contaminated seafood poses significant health risks for human consumption, particularly in communities relying heavily on marine foods as a source of nutrition and socio-economic wellbeing
1, 14, 15 .
